newsitem.title: USA: Tropical storm Jo gains strength in Gulf of Mexico.
newsitem.headline: Tropical storm Jo gains strength in Gulf of Mexico.

text.p: Tropical Storm Josephine gained strength as it headed across the Gulf of Mexico Monday on a track that would take it ashore in Florida Tuesday, National Hurricane Center said.
A tropical storm warning -- alerting residents to imminent storm conditions -- was in effect for the Florida Gulf coast from Apalachicola to Venice.

At 0500 EDT/0900 GMT, the center of Josephine was at latitude 25.8 north, longitude 88.4 west, about 340 miles (545 km) southwest of Apalachicola, and was moving toward the east-northeast at 15 mph (24 kph), forecasters said.
On its current track and speed, the center of the storm will move onshore early Tuesday morning, but tropical storm force winds will reach the Florida coast Monday, forecasters said.
Maximum winds were near 50 mph (80 kph) and some strengthening was likely in the next 24 hours, forecasters said.

Tropical storm-force winds extended outward about 145 miles (230 km) from the center, mainly to the southeast. Rainfall of up to 5 inches (13 cm) was possible along the track of the storm, along with strong onshore winds and coastal storm surge flooding of three to five feet (one to two meters).

The Hurricane Center said weather in the Gulf was complicated by a strong pressure gradient between Josephine and high pressure to the north, which was causing strong winds elsewhere over the northern Gulf of Mexico.
